title: Cat tax? çŒ«ç¨ï¼Ÿ
text:
Chinese Friends, why do you ask for the "cat tax"?
ä¸­å›½æœ‹å‹ä»¬ï¼Œä½ ä»¬ä¸ºä»€ä¹ˆè¦æ±‚å¾æ”¶â€œçŒ«ç¨â€å‘¢ï¼Ÿ
I understand that cats are very cute and here in America we too enjoy looking at cats. I am curious however if the cat tax is a cultural thing, or simply a joke that has arisen with the influx of Americans into xiaohongshu?
 
Also, in America we have slang where we call cats cars, as the letter r is right next to t on our keyboards, so it is a common spelling error that many have started to do on purpose, since the noise a cat makes is similar to a car engine. Is there a similar slang in Mandarin? Thanks!

title: The word â€œforeignerâ€ is outdated
text:
I spent 14 years living in China, and one word that consistently grated on me was "foreigner." It always felt like a label, a box I was being placed in, rather than a recognition of my individual identity.
The term "foreigner" implies an outsider, someone inherently different and perhaps even unwelcome. It lacks the nuance and respect that should be given to individuals from diverse backgrounds.
There are far more appropriate and welcoming terms available. "Westerner," while not perfect, could be more inclusive and respectful in many contexts.
Even here in Canada, I've encountered this term used by Chinese people. It's particularly jarring to experience this in my own country, where l am a citizen. This highlights the need for greater awareness and sensitivity around the use of this term, not just in other countries but also within our own communities.

title: My TT Refugee Story (aka Insta Escape)
text:
Short version: I'm in my healing era, and this is my chance to start fresh and more
"anonymous" (ironic, considering how many Rednote users there are).
 
Long version: I've always loved content creation-not for fame or trends, but for the artistic and aesthetic joy of it (Iâ€™ve never been famous or viral). But everything changed in 2021 when I became a mom.
My pregnancy was rough, I lost myself, my energy, and my confidence. I tried posting, but the internet felt more toxic-full of judgment because "you're a mom now, act like one."
 
When my second baby was born in 2023, I left social media entirely. But I missed creating. Then, I saw a makeup artist mention her "retreat" to Rednote, and here I am. Nobody I know uses this app (family, friends or my colleagues) so l finally feel free to create, share, and enjoy myself again.
 
Thanks for reading!

title: TIKTOK REFUGEEæˆ‘å­¦ä¹ ä¸­æ–‡ with these apps
text:
Iâ€™m a tiktok refugee like you, and iâ€™m learning Chinese with these apps.
- Hello Chinese (my favorite, native chinese speakers, great for spoken language practice. It has simulated conversations where it role plays with you and you converse vocally for the lesson)
 
- å°çº¢ä¹¦(xiaohongshu). Little Red Book: thereâ€™s a ton of content created by chinese teachers that i am learning from. Find your favorites and follow them! å°çº¢ä¹¦+Hello Chinese has taught me the most
- duolingo (i wish i found Hello Chinese first)
 
- HanziPro (from a creator here on rednote. A spaced-repitition driven flash card app. great so far!)
- Chineasy (it is great and i think i would love it, visual learning for hanzi. But only the first 8 levels are free)
- Anki (spaced reputition flash cards. I downloaded a deck from online with many vocabulary and i think it will be good once i have more knowledge, but i need some additional context to help with learning Hanzi.)  #tiktok_refugee #learnchinese #nihao
